job_title: Physician Referral Coordinator in Chicago, IL
pros: Amazing physicians hands on patient care Good location Available parking
cons: Director is not in tune with what is going on within the department, high turn over rate within a year. No communication within department. Clinic is busy, because of short staffing unable to take lunch and you are unable to be reimbursed for that lost lunch, when requesting for reimbursement for lunch you are made to feel like you did not do everything you could to step away to take lunch. High work load because of short staffing , you end up doing jobs that are out of your scope or what you are hired for. If you are hired to work on background administration duties, management will still pull you away from your duties to check in patients this takes away from your work load. Employees who have been there years there is no way to grow your career.

job_title: Clinical Exercise Physiologist in Chicago, IL
pros: Swedish is a small community hospital so it has always felt like a family and I have always felt supported. It's located in one of the most diverse zip codes in the country and the organization does a great job celebrating each and every culture. It has felt like working in a family. Benefits are also good.
cons: This is not a Swedish problem (I don't think), but I am living paycheck to paycheck every single week, in addition to working two other jobs. We only get 1% raises for doing a stellar job and getting shining annual reviews. So there is not much motivation to go above and beyond if you aren't going to be compensated for it. But my salary is "competetive" compared to other median salaries for this job title. I also have no areas for growth here unless I go back to school, which is hard to do with $20,000 of debt under your belt still.

review_title: Cruel, incompetent management, low pay, every department understaffed
pros:
-I love the neighborhood and patient population (close ties to the surrounding community)
-The company seems to value diversity and respects other cultures
-Most physicians and staff members I have worked with are kind and respectful and actually care about their patients.
cons:
-Very low pay compared to other hospitals in the area
-Non-clinical managers oversee clinical staff. Management does not understand clinical staff's job, and more importantly they do not care. They don't listen to their staff, lots of unnecessary meetings where we are getting reprimanded for things that don't matter while mgmt is ignoring things that actually effect the patients and staff retention. They will read out loud all the patient complaints to shame the staff, yet show absolutely no interest in actually improving things. Management by fear, up to the CEO, everything is about intimidation here, and that's why they turnover is high.
-Every single department is understaffed. EVERY SINGLE ONE.
-Promotions are often unwarranted, there is a lot of favoritism here.

pros: Good and cooperative staff to work with
cons: as in all work in environments, there always the "a lazy one" who manages to breeze on by though the rest of the groups hard and cooperative work

pros: Great coworkers, fun, nice, easy.
cons: Low pay, bad management, rude management, micro management.

pros: great co-workers to work with during the hectic days
cons: management is all over the place and workload is immense

review_title: Well-rounded experience for those interested in pursuing Physical Therapy
pros: Diverse therapy experiences, discount at the Galter Life Center, good benefits
cons: Sometimes short on staff, increased clerical work

pros: Family feel. Great opportunities for advancement.
cons: Equitable pay when compared to broader healthcare marketplace.

pros:
Working with hospital staff and laboratory technicians is great. 
Everyone is very friendly and tries to be helpful. 
Lots of opportunities to interact with nurses and some doctors.
cons:
Hard to request days off. Requests get denied often. 
Scheduling conflicts happen often. 
co-workers often call off or are no shows. It puts more work and stress on the employees that do show up and work. 
NO OVERTIME ALLOTTED. Manager constantly dips into PTO hours, without proper notification. 
Weak upper management skills. Upper management is constantly shouting/yelling at employees, saying rude comments, or be dismissive entirely to all staff members. 

VERY DIFFICULT to move up in this position. considers a promotion after  a minimum of 3 years.

pros: Coworkers, close to home, the staff tends to support one another, the parking lot is large and affordable, large amount of PTO starting out
cons: Management, no ability for upward movement, very little value in employee satisfaction. Yearly reviews are a joke the raise is standard across the hospital and has nothing to do with an individual's merit or abilities. HR is a joke every response is go to the website they could eliminate the entire department and people prolly wouldn't notice a difference

review_title: Some of the people are wonderful, management lacking
pros: Some wonderful people who actually care about patients work here, you can gain a lot of clinical experience here as a social worker, the parking is affordable and accessible, the social work and case manager continuing education options are good
cons: Management  of the SW/CM department micromanages and uses demeaning language towards employees, they also lead by fear and often create unnecessary chaos, HR sides with management, health insurance options were poor, some of the physicians were cruel in their communications with staff

pros:
-community-based hospital treating a diverse population with most staff living nearby
-benefits are good
cons:
-Low pay
-no room for advancement
-chronically understaffed
-resistant to adopting/updating useful technologies (even basic technology, like the phones), resulting in inefficient, disorganized, inconsistent workflow
-cronyism and clique mentality among management – hiring/promoting unqualified people; those in management positions have been in those positions for decades and are rigid in their thinking, so there is no innovation or willingness to change; management does not share information with staff; errors made by entrenched staff unfairly attributed to newer or less powerful staff
-Non-clinical managers or managers of different disciplines for clinical staff, managers are ignorant of staff members’ training and duties, do not recognize the need for further discussion/training/education, make unrealistic/inappropriate demands of staff, cannot provide meaningful supervision/support or critical feedback, and either do not invite or ignore feedback and suggestions from staff
-Competent, dedicated staff are undervalued and unappreciated; no efforts made in the interest of employee retention, resulting in frequent turnover, usually with underqualified people because more experienced people expect higher pay
-Punitive atmosphere, and yet the same mistakes (some significant and unethical) are made repeatedly with no apparent correction – staff are often “written up” but there is no teaching/coaching provided to address the issue and no one is held responsible for serious or repeated errors
-generally a reactive approach rather than a proactive one; management seems unable or unwilling to anticipate needs and problems and is not receptive to staff who attempt to do so
-Poor role definition, e.g., secretaries performing the duties of CNAs, clinical staff expected to provide more than occasional secretarial support
-Paternalistic/“big brother” atmosphere – unable to access even basic internet (e.g., google) on many hospital computers despite needing to do so to efficiently perform job duties, expected to provide detailed medical information (lab results, blood pressure readings, etc) to HR or pay more for insurance

pros: you work with a great group of individuals and there is a genuine family atmosphere in many of the patient care units.
cons: The hourly rate when compared to other hospitals on the north-side is lacking.  It also sounds like the attendance and tardiness policy is continually changing so some staff are complaining that its impossible to figure out where you stand if you need to take an emergency day off.

review_title: In the past it was a great place to work, not so much anymore
pros: Co-workers are great and there is a real team spirit among us. Generally a good relationship between physicians and nursing staff
cons: Management has turned the place into an over the top penny pinching organization that skimps on everything yet wonders why employee satisfaction is in the dumps.

review_title: My 2 years at Swedish were less than satisfactory
pros: If you live in the north side of Chicago,it is close to home.Being a hospital,easy access to Doctors
cons: Very bureaucratic,not very performance oriented,a small hospital and thus less opportunities to grow.If you are ambitious and want to move ahead,unfortunately not the place to be.

pros: Gives employment opportunity to new grads. Hourly rate is decent.
